articles.author: Fatima Faizi and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
articles.title: For Women in Kabul, ‘It Is Just Me and the Water’
articles.description: Since 2001, 23 public and private pools have appeared in Kabul, but only two allow women. They’re a welcome refuge from suicide bombings and the threat of a Taliban takeover.
articles.content: KABUL, Afghanistan When Fatema Saeedi is in the pool, she cannot hear the crowded, chaotic noise of the city around her. She does not think about suicide bombings or Taliban attacks. She concentrates on her breathing as she moves through the water. One hand i… [+658 chars]

articles.title: Afghan President Declared in Lead of Disputed Vote as Opposition Protests
articles.description: Initial results of the September elections, which had been delayed, show President Ashraf Ghani leading with 50.64 percent of the vote.

articles.author: Reuters
articles.title: The Best Year Financial Markets Have Ever Had?
articles.description: For all the angst about trade wars, geopolitics and a sputtering and overly indebted global economy, 2019 might just be the best year investors have ever had.
articles.content: U.S. Treasuries, the world's benchmark government IOU, have made a whopping 9.4 percent after yields plunged as much as 120 basis points. That followed a near 40 basis point fall the last quarter of 2018, after five quarters in which they had consistently ris… [+1317 chars]

For Saeedi, 26, the swimming pool is a refuge. The clean water, the walls and the women around her all sealed off from the male patrons nearby are a welcome respite from Kabul, Afghanistans capital.

articles.title: In France, Holiday Skating Rinks Are an Unlikely Climate Battleground
articles.description: The attractions have prompted environmental concerns, and some cities have canceled them, citing the size of the carbon footprint needed to maintain the sites.
articles.content:
In St.-Malo, Damien Chalmet, 34, was skating with his 5-year-old son.

articles.title: Boeing Starliner Landing: What You Need to Know
articles.description: The new ride to orbit built for NASA is returning to Earth early after problems during its first trip to space on Friday.
articles.content:
